questions.text: This fundus appearance is seen in which form of refractive error?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myopia

 

Option A.

 

This fundus picture shows:

 

  • Mild tilting of disc
  • Characteristic temporal crescent
  • Grossly tessellated background

 

All these above-mentioned features are suggestive of Myopia.

 

Additional features:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypermetropia: Optic Disc: The optic nerve head may appear smaller or may have a crowded appearance due to the smaller eye size typically associated with hypermetropia. This can sometimes be mistaken for papilledema, which is swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure.

 

Option C. Astigmatism: There is no characteristic fundus findings in eyes with astigmatism.

 

Option D. Presbyopia: There are no characteristic findings in eyes with presbyopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tessellated fundus is most commonly seen in myopia, as the retinal thinning associated with this condition makes the choroidal vessels more apparent, giving the retina its characteristic mosaic-like appearance.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 35

questions.text: A cataract surgery with a premium multifocal intraocular lens implantation is being planned. To assess the suitability of the patient to the MFIOL, the surgeon is evaluating the angle alpha of the patient. Angle alpha is between:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optical Axis and Visual Axis

 

Option A.

 

  • The Optical Axis is an imaginary line that passes through the center of the cornea and the center of the crystalline lens.
  • The Visual Axis is the line that connects the fovea with the point of focus on the object being viewed.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fixation Axis and Optical Axis: The Fixation Axis (also known as the Line of Sight) is the line connecting the fovea with the object of regard (the point one is looking directly at).

 

Option C. Visual Axis and Fixation Axis: As described, the visual axis connects the fovea with the point of focus on the object, while the fixation axis is essentially the same, connecting the fovea to the object of regard.

 

Option D. Optical Axis and Pupillary Line: The Pupillary Line is a line drawn perpendicularly from the center of the pupil to the object of regard.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angle Alpha is the angle between the optical axis and the visual axis of the eye, which is a key consideration in the alignment of corrective lenses for optimal vision correction.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 27

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. On examination it was seen that his pupil was jet black and the Purkinje image test revealed only two images. What is likely to be the conclusion after performing retinoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Hypermetropia

 

Option C:

 

  • The clinical signs – a jet black pupil, and presence of only two Purkinje images - point towards aphakia.
  • Total power of the eye is reduced from +60D to about +44D – hence eye becomes highly hypermetropic.
  • On performing retinoscopy on a hypermetropic/emmetropic/ myopic eye with power <1D: the red reflex is along movement.
  • To correct high hypermetropia, high power plus lenses are used.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Low Hypermetropia: Hypermetropia (farsightedness) occurs when the eye is too short or the lens is too weak, causing light to focus behind the retina. However, the absence of the lens in aphakia leads to a much more significant refractive error than what would be classified as "low" hypermetropia.

 

Option B. Low Myopia: Myopia (near-sightedness) is when the eye is too long or the lens is too strong, causing light to focus in front of the retina. Aphakia does not typically result in myopia, as the removal of the lens significantly reduces the eye's refractive power.

 

Option D. High Myopia: As mentioned, aphakia generally does not lead to myopia. The condition results in a loss of refractive power, not an excess of it, which would be necessary to cause high myopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In aphakic patients, where the natural lens of the eye is absent, retinoscopy typically reveals high hypermetropia due to the significant reduction in the eye's refractive power.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 31

questions.text: Identify the type of lens in this picture:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rigid Gas Permeable Lens

 

Option B:

 

  • Oxygen-permeable or rigid gas-permeable lenses are made of a firm, durable plastic that transmits oxygen.
  • Materials used include copolymer of PMMA and silicone and cellulose acetate butyrate.
  • As they do not contain water, they resist deposits and are less likely than soft contact lenses to harbor bacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Soft Contact Lens: Made of soft, flexible plastics that allow oxygen to pass through to the cornea, soft contact lenses are comfortable and easier to adapt to than rigid lenses.

 

Option C. Hard Contact Lens: Made of a rigid, durable plastic, hard contact lenses are less comfortable and less oxygen-permeable compared to soft or rigid gas permeable lenses and are rarely used today.

 

Option D. Scleral Contact Lens: Large-diameter lenses that vault over the entire corneal surface and rest on the sclera, scleral lenses are used for specific corneal irregularities and provide comfort for sensitive eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigid Gas Permeable Lens: are more durable than soft contact lenses, provide clearer vision, and are breathable, allowing more oxygen to reach the cornea.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 82

choices.text: This procedure uses Excimer Laser
Done in Myopes > 21 years of age
Needs a stable Refractive Error

questions.text: All are true regarding LASIK except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Indicated in Keratoconus

 

Option D:

 

  • Laser assisted in situ keratomileusis, or LASIK is done with the excimer laser.
  • Patient selection criteria:
    • Minimum 21 years of age.
    • Stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
    • Have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
    • Corneal thinning disorders (like Keratoconus) that lead to curvatural myopia have been ruled out.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This procedure uses excimer laser: True. LASIK surgery uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea, which corrects refractive errors like myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism.

 

Option B. Done in myopes > 21 years of age: True. LASIK is typically performed on patients over the age of 21 when the refractive error is more likely to have stabilized.

 

Option C. Needs a stable refractive error: True. A stable refractive error for at least a year is one of the prerequisites for LASIK, to ensure the long-term effectiveness of the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LASIK should not be performed on patients with keratoconus.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 74

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with aphakia in the right eye presents for vision correction. The ophthalmologist prescribes spectacles to address the refractive error. During the examination, a specific type of visual distortion or aberration is observed in the right eye. What is the likely aberration noted?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pin Cushion

 

Option B:

 

  • Spectacle correction in aphakia causes spherical aberration in the form of pincushion effect.
  • Image appears pinched in the center.
  • Image distortion increases progressively in both directions.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Barrel Distortion: This occurs when the magnification of the image decreases with increasing distance from the optical axis. In optics, it is seen with high minus lenses.

 

Option C. Coma: This aberration occurs when an optical system images an off-axis point source, resulting in an asymmetric, comet-like blur. In the human eye, coma can be caused by imperfections in the lens or corneal surface, often exacerbated under conditions of large pupil diameters.

 

Option D. Oblique Astigmatism: This type of astigmatism happens when light rays entering the eye off the optical axis have different refractive errors in different meridians. It's not specific to aphakia but is a common issue in spectacle and contact lens corrections, especially when the gaze is directed significantly away from the optical center of the lens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an aphakic patient corrected with spectacles, "Pin Cushion Distortion" is the typical visual aberration observed, where the strong positive lenses cause straight lines to appear curved inwards due to increased magnification away from the lens's optical axis.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 77

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinoscope

 

Option A:

 

  • Retinoscopy or Skiascopy or the shadow test is the most practical method of estimating the condition of the refraction objectively.
  • Works on the principle of neutralization.
  • Types – spot and streak retinoscope.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Direct Ophthalmoscope  

 

 

Option C. Perkin’s tonometer

 

 

Option D. Focimeter

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The instrument shown is a streal retinoscope.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 59

questions.text: A 23-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurring of vision since the past few months. During evaluation, she is subjected to retinoscopic refraction wherein the streak of light and the shadow moved in opposite directions. Based on this, what is the refractive error she is likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Myopia >1D.

 

Option D:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypermetropia > 1D: Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, is indicated by "with motion" in retinoscopy (where the light streak and shadow move in the same direction), not "against motion".

 

Option B. Myopia < 1D: Produces with movement.

 

Option C. Hypermetropia < 1D: Similar to option A, hypermetropia would not present with "with motion" in retinoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retinoscopy, if the streak of light and the shadow move in opposite directions (against motion), it typically indicates myopia, and the speed of the shadow's movement can help determine the degree of myopia. A quick shadow movement against the light streak suggests myopia greater than 1 diopter.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 59

questions.text: Based on this image, Focal interval is between?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B and F

 

Explanation:

 

  • The distance between the two foci in Sturm’s conoid is called the focal interval of Sturm.
  • At one place in this focal interval there will be a spot (D) where the vertical rays have diverged from the axis exactly as much as the horizontal rays have converged towards it. Here the cross-section is a circle, which is called the circle of least diffusion.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye 22nd edition page 52-53

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a Mydriatic but not a Cycloplegic?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phenylephrine

 

Option D: Mydriasis refers to dilatation of pupil. It can be carried out by 2 mechanisms:

 

  • Active mydriasis: Sympathomimetic (Phenylephrine)
  • Passive mydriasis: Anticholiergic (Atropine)

 

Cycloplegia refers to absence of accommodation due to paralysis of ciliary muscle. It is carried out by anticholinergic drugs that block muscarinic receptor-mediated contraction of ciliary muscle.

 

  • Phenylephrine 5–10%, a selective alpha-1 agonist acts on dilator pupillae only. It does not act on ciliary muscle hence does not cause cycloplegia. Always to be used in combination with cycloplegics pre-op.
  • Used prior to fundus examination or retinal laser procedures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cyclopentolate: This is both a mydriatic and a cycloplegic agent. It dilates the pupil and also temporarily paralyzes the ciliary muscle, leading to loss of accommodation.

 

Option B. Homatropine: Like cyclopentolate, homatropine is also both a mydriatic and a cycloplegic. It dilates the pupil and affects accommodation.

 

Option C. Atropine: This is another example of a drug that is both a mydriatic and a cycloplegic. It causes prolonged pupil dilation and paralysis of accommodation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenylephrine is a mydriatic agent used to dilate the pupil without causing significant cycloplegia, making it suitable for procedures where pupil dilation is needed without affecting the eye's focusing ability.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 155

questions.text: What is true for SMILE surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Small Incision Lenticule Extraction

 

Option B: SMILE

 

Small Incision Lenticule Extraction

 

  • Refractive surgery
  • Extraction of refractive lenticule
  • Through a small cut in the corneal flap
  • Can be done manually or with femto laser.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Small incision Lens extraction: It is a method of extracapsular cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Also known as Phacoemulsification: Phacoemulsification is a method of extracapsular cataract surgery.

 

Option D. Partial thickness keratoplasty: Also known as lamellar corneal grafting, this is a type of corneal transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SMILE is a type of refractive surgery.

 

Ref: Pg 396/ theory & practise of optics & refraction/ 4th edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: For a patient scheduled for cataract surgery, a pharmacological agent was administered before the procedure to prevent intraoperative miosis. This drug, commonly used in such cases, helps maintain pupil dilation during surgery, facilitating optimal visualization of the surgical field. Identify the drug that was administered.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 0.03% Flurbiprofen

 

Option B: Flurbiprofen is an NSAID.

 

During surgery, there is a release of prostaglandins which causes miosis. This is prevented by NSAIDs through cyclooxygenase pathway inhibition.

 

Other alternatives:

 

  • Indomethacin 0.5%- 1%
  • Ketorolac 0.4%

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1% Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that causes pupil dilation (mydriasis) and paralysis of accommodation (cycloplegia).

 

Option C. 10% Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonist that induces mydriasis without cycloplegia. It is often used in cataract surgery to maintain pupil dilation. Its rapid onset and effectiveness in dilating the pupil make it a common choice for this purpose.

 

Option D. 0.5% Proparacaine is a topical anesthetic used in ophthalmology to anesthetise the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug administered to prevent intraoperative miosis during cataract surgery is 0.03% Flurbiprofen, an NSAID, as it specifically targets the prevention of miosis during surgical procedures. While phenylephrine is also a mydriatic agent, its primary role is not the prevention of miosis but rather the induction of mydriasis. Flurbiprofen's role in inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis directly counteracts the factors that cause miosis during surgery.

 

Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22nd Edition Page 155

questions.text: In a child undergoing cataract surgery, which of the following is added to the irrigating solution to prevent postoperative inflammatory membrane formation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heparin         

 

Option C: The role of infusion fluid during cataract surgery:

 

  1. To aid in the smooth removal of the lens and
  2. Restore the aqueous humor at the end of the procedure.

 

Additives to Infusion Fluid:

 

  1. Preservative-Free Antibiotics – Prophylaxis
  2. Adrenaline 0.3ml of 1:1000 in 500ml – to maintain Mydriasis.
  3. Preservative free Low Molecular Weight Heparin 10 IU/ml – prevent postoperative severe fibrinous inflammatory membrane formation in children.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adrenaline (Epinephrine) is often added to local anesthetic solutions to constrict blood vessels, thereby reducing bleeding and prolonging the duration of anesthesia. While it may help in maintaining pupil dilation during surgery, it is not primarily used for controlling postoperative inflammation.

 

Option B. Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that causes dilation of the pupil and paralysis of accommodation. It is not typically used in the irrigating solution during cataract surgery, and its primary role is not in controlling postoperative inflammation.

 

Option D. Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. While it is commonly used in ophthalmology for controlling inflammation, it is typically administered as an eye drop or injection, not in the irrigating solution during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heparin is added to the irrigating solution during pediatric cataract surgery to prevent the formation of postoperative inflammatory membranes.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF THE EYE PAGE 158

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of cardiac arrhythmia is currently receiving treatment with Amiodarone. The patient complains of defective vision, prompting an ophthalmic evaluation. Given the patient's medication history, what is the probable form of cataract that may be observed in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior Subcapsular Cataract

 

Option A:

 

  • Amiodarone is a class 3 antiarrythmic.
  • Mechanism of action: Potassium channel blocker
  • Ocular complications include:
    • Keratopathy
    • Anterior subcapsular cataract
    • Optic neuropathy
    • Pigmentary retinopathy
    • Pseudotumor cerebri

 

Other important adverse effects:

 

  • Blue/grey skin deposits
  • Hypo/hyperthyroidism
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Bradycardia
  • Hepatotoxic
  • Constipation

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Posterior Polar Cataract is located at the posterior pole of the lens and is often due to congenital posterior capsular dehiscence. It has a whirl like appearance.


 

Option C. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC) forms under the posterior capsule of the lens. This type of cataract is associated with several factors, including long-term use of corticosteroids, radiation, and intraocular inflammation.

 

It has a bread crump appearance

 

 

Option D. Anterior Polar Cataract forms at the front pole of the lens and is often congenital. It's not typically associated with medication use like Amiodarone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is associated with anterior subcapsular cataract.

 

Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22nd Edition Page 367

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive vision loss in both eyes over the past few months. Upon examination, a swollen, bulging lens with increased lens thickness is observed. The diagnosis of intumescent cataract is made. What is the diameter of a normal adult crystalline lens?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 9 – 11 mm

 

Explanation:

 

Diameter of the lens:

 

  • At Birth            = 6.5 mm
  • Adult                = 9 to 11 mm

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diameter if normal crystalline lens is 9-11 mm.

 

Ref: Pg 110/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eyeball /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A patient evaluated for cataract surgery also had residual cylinder power correction needed. What would be the procedure of choice to address both the situations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phacomeulsification with Toric IOLS implantation

 

Option B:

 

  • Toric IOLs refers to astigmatism correcting intraocular lenses used at the time of cataract surgery to decrease astigmatism.
  • The patient should have visually significant cataract and astigmatism.
  • They can be used to correct corneal astigmatism of 1D and above.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TORIC ICL (Implantable Collamer Lens) Implantation are used to correct refractive errors, including myopia and astigmatism. However, they are not typically used for cataract surgery. ICLs are implanted in addition to the natural lens and are more commonly used in refractive surgery for patients without cataracts.

 

Option C. While phacoemulsification with the implantation of a multifocal IOL is an effective treatment for cataracts and can provide a range of vision (near to far), multifocal IOLs do not specifically correct astigmatism. They are more focused on reducing the need for reading glasses or bifocals post-surgery.

 

Option D. MSICS (Manual Small Incision Cataract Surgery) is an effective method for cataract removal, especially in developing countries or in cases where phacoemulsification equipment is not available. However, this procedure does not inherently correct astigmatism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate choice for a patient needing both cataract surgery and astigmatism correction is Phacoemulsification with Toric IOLs Implantation. This option directly addresses the cataract through phacoemulsification and corrects astigmatism with the implantation of a toric IOL.

 

Ref: Pg 310/ Intraocular Lenses/ Theory & Practise of Optics of Refraction

questions.text: A cataract surgeon noticed zonular dehiscence in a patient preoperatively of less than 2 clock hours. What precaution can be taken during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capsular Tension Rings (CTR) Insertion

 

Option D.

 

  • The presence of zonular weakness increases the risk of intra- and postoperative complications from cataract surgery, including posterior capsular rupture, vitreous loss, and lens dislocation and decentration.
  • Capsular support devices facilitate safe and successful cataract surgery by improving capsular bag stability and centration.
  • These devices consist of capsular tension rings (A), modified capsular tension rings (B), capsular tension segments (C), and capsular retention hooks (D). 


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iris hooks are used to mechanically dilate the pupil in cases where pharmacological dilation is insufficient. While they provide better visualization during surgery, they do not address zonular dehiscence or the stability of the lens capsule.

 

Option B. Multifocal IOLs provide a range of vision post-cataract surgery but have no role in managing zonular dehiscence. The choice of IOL doesn't directly impact the surgical approach to zonular weakness.

 

Option C. LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis) is a refractive surgery procedure for correcting vision issues like myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism. It is unrelated to the management of zonular dehiscence in cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the scenario of zonular dehiscence of less than 2 clock hours, the precaution that can be taken during cataract surgery is - Capsular Tension Rings (CTR) insertion. This approach helps to manage the weakened zonular support effectively, ensuring a safer surgical procedure and better outcomes.

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Capsular_Support_Devices

questions.text: In FLACS (Femto Laser Assisted Cataract Surgery), what is the Femto Laser used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D.

 

  • Femtosecond laser assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) is a recent development in the history of cataract surgery.
  • The femtosecond laser can be used to create cleavage planes via photo disruption in transparent/translucent tissues.
  • The laser can be used to assist the surgeon by creating tissue planes for:
    1. Wounds
    2. Arcuate Keratotomies
    3. Anterior Capsulotomies
    4. Nuclear Fragmentation

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior Capsulotomy: The femtosecond laser is used to create a precise, circular incision in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is a critical step for accessing and removing the cataract. This laser-assisted capsulotomy is known for its precision and reproducibility compared to the manual technique.

 

Option B. Arcuate Keratotomies: The femtosecond laser can also be used to perform arcuate keratotomies, which are precise incisions in the cornea to correct pre-existing astigmatism. This enhances the refractive outcomes of cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Nuclear Fragmentation: The femtosecond laser can pre-fragment the cataractous lens (nucleus) which can reduce the amount of ultrasound energy (phacoemulsification) needed to subsequently break up and remove the lens material, potentially leading to less trauma to the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The femtosecond laser in FLACS is a versatile tool that enhances the precision, safety, and refractive outcomes of cataract surgery by assisting in multiple key steps of the procedure.

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Femtosecond_Cataract_Surgery

questions.text: In case of posterior capsular rupture, where are the GLUED IOLs placed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Behind the Iris

 

Option C.

 

  • The glued IOL technique is a relatively new method for fixing a posterior chamber IOL in an eye without a capsule.
  • The glued IOL technique consists of making two partial-thickness scleral flaps exactly 180 degrees apart.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. In the Anterior Chamber IOLs are placed in front of the iris. This option is generally considered when there is inadequate support in the posterior chamber, but it's less favored due to potential complications like corneal endothelial damage and secondary glaucoma.

 

 

 

Option B. Attached to Iris-fixated IOLs are another option where the lens is attached to the iris. This can be done in cases where there is insufficient capsular support, but it requires sufficient structural integrity of the iris and careful consideration of potential complications, such as iris chafing.

 

 

Option D. None of the Above: This option is incorrect given that one of the above choices accurately describes the placement of glued IOLs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that in cases of posterior capsular rupture, glued intraocular lenses (IOLs) are typically placed in the sulcus, behind the iris, using a technique that secures the IOL to the sclera with fibrin glue for stable fixation.

 

Ref:  https://www.aao.org/education/current-insight/glued-iol-technique

choices.text: Extended Depth of Focus IOL.

questions.text: Which of the following IOLs is used to correct both distant & near vision?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IOLs used for correcting both distant & near vision together include:

 

  • Trifocal iols
  • Bifocal IOLs or Multifocal IOLs
  • Diffractive iols
  • Accommodative IOLs
  • Extended Depth of Focus IOL.

 

Ref:  Pg 310/ Theory & Practise of Optics & Refraction/ 4th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Identify the type of IOL.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multifocal IOLs

 

Option D:

 

  • Annulus type of multifocal IOL.
  • The central portion of the optics contains distance vision refraction and near vision ring outside it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A Monofocal Intra-Ocular Lens (IOL) is an artificial lens implanted in the eye that has a single fixed focus, typically set for distance vision, requiring the use of glasses for near tasks.

 

Option B. Accommodative IOLs are advanced artificial lenses designed to move or change shape inside the eye, mimicking the eye's natural ability to change focus (accommodation) between distant and near objects.

 

 

Option C. Piggyback IOLs involve the implantation of a second intraocular lens over an existing IOL, usually to correct residual refractive errors such as residual myopia, hyperopia, or astigmatism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multifocal IOLs are artificial lenses implanted in the eye that have multiple focus zones built into the lens, allowing for clear vision at various distances, reducing or eliminating the need for glasses.

 

Ref: Pg 317/ Theory & Practise of Optics & Refraction/ 4th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 55-year-old male diagnosed with right eye immature cataract was planned for cataract surgery. But there was poor pupillary dilatation. The technique shown in the image for dilating the pupil is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iris Hooks

 

Option C:

 

  • Iris Hook Technique is useful in patients with small pupils and posterior synechiae.
  • For dilating the pupil.
  • By marking the 4 incision sites for the hooks in a diamond configuration. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sphincterotomy is a surgical procedure to cut the iris sphincter to achieve mechanical mydriasis.

 

Option B. Phacoemulsification is a modern cataract surgery technique in which an ultrasound device is used to emuslsify cataract within the eye.

 

Option D. Trabeculectomy is a surgical procedure to treat glaucoma by creating a drainage fistula in the eye's sclera and trabecular meshwork to lower intraocular pressure by allowing aqueous humor to drain into the subconjunctival space bypassing the trabecular meshwork.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iris hooks are small devices used during eye surgery to mechanically dilate the pupil and provide better access and visibility, especially in cases where the pupil does not dilate sufficiently on its own.

 

Ref: https://www.aao.org/education/clinical-video/iris-hook-technique

questions.text: Which of the following is derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Structures derived from Surface Ectoderm:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The surface ectoderm gives rise to crystalline lens, epithelium of cornea and epithelium of conjunctiva.

 

 

Ref: Pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE Ophthalmology/ 6th Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with severe ocular pain and redness accompanied with dimunition in vision and discharge. After extensive examination, he was diagnosed with endophthalmitis. Which is the preferred combination of intravitreal antibiotics you will prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1mg Vancomycin + 2.25mg Ceftazidime

 

Option B:

 

  • Intravitreal antibiotics are the treatment of choice for endophthalmitis.
  • Injected after taking a 0.2–0.3 ml vitreous biopsy for preparing smears and obtaining cultures.
  • A combination of vancomycin (1mg) and ceftazidime (2.25mg) is the preferred combination.
  • Amikacin (0.4 mg in 0.1 ml) or gentamicin (0.4 mg in 0.1 ml) are used less frequently owing to the risk of macular infarction.
  • Simultaneous injection of dexamethasone 0.4 mg in 0.1 ml is optional.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 0.1mg Moxifloxacin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, but it is not commonly used alone as an intravitreal injection for the treatment of endophthalmitis. Monotherapy is generally less favored due to the diverse range of potential infective organisms.

 

Option C. 1mg Vancomycin + 0.4mg Gentamycin: While this combination provides broad coverage against both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms, the use of Gentamycin has declined due to its potential toxicity, particularly the risk of macular ischaemia.

 

Option D. 2.25mg Ceftazidime + 0.4mg Amikacin: Ceftazidime covers gram-negative bacteria, and Amikacin is another aminoglycoside like Gentamycin. Like Gentamycin, Amikacin has potential toxicities. This combination, while effective, is generally less preferred due to the concerns of macular ischaemia associated with aminoglycosides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate and preferred combination for treating endophthalmitis is 1mg Vancomycin + 2.25mg Ceftazidime. This combination is broadly effective against the range of bacteria typically implicated in endophthalmitis and is the standard of care in many clinical settings.

 

Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22nd Edition Page 243

questions.text: A patient who underwent an ocular surgery a week back, now complaints of pain, redness, photophobia and decrease in vision. The surgeon suspects post-operative endophthalmitis. Which of the following topical drugs is known to reduce the risk of post-operative endophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5% Povidone Iodine

 

Option B:

 

  • Topical povidone-iodine solution, 5% exhibits broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity when used to prepare the surgical field and to rinse the ocular surface.
  • It is the only drug that has had a significant effect on prevention of postsurgical endophthalmitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1% Azithromycin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic and can be used topically for bacterial infections of the eye. However, it is not the primary agent known for reducing the risk of post-operative endophthalmitis.

 

Option C. 0.5% Moxifloxacin: Moxifloxacin is a fourth-generation fluoroquinolone antibiotic used topically for bacterial infections of the eye. While it is effective against a range of bacteria, its primary use is not specifically for reducing the risk of post-operative endophthalmitis in the same preventive capacity as povidone iodine.

 

Option D. 5% Vancomycin is an antibiotic that can be used to treat serious bacterial infections, including Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It's not typically used as a prophylactic measure against post-operative endophthalmitis in a topical form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective and commonly used agent for reducing the risk of post-operative endophthalmitis is 5% Povidone Iodine. This antiseptic solution is applied preoperatively to the ocular surface to minimize the presence of potential infectious agents.

 

Ref: AAO Section: 2 – 2020 Edition Page 428

questions.text: A Myopic patient was posted for Radial Keratotomy. What is the size of the optical zone left while making Peripheral Corneal Incisions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Radial Keratotomy is one of the Surgical Procedures done for correction of Myopia.
  • It is a type of Refractive Keratoplasty which is done to Modify the Refractive Power of the Cornea.
  • In this, Multiple Radial Incisions are made in the periphery of the cornea leaving a Central 4mm Optical Zone.
  • These incisions on Healing cause Flattening of the Corneal Curvature.

 

Education Objective:

 

Central Optional Zone in Radial Keratotomy is 4mm.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 592

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with blurred and distorted vision. After a comprehensive eye examination, she is diagnosed with irregular astigmatism. What is the treatment of choice for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contact Lens

 

Option B:

 

  • Irregular astigmatism is a condition wherein refraction varies in multiple meridians which are not perpendicular to one-another.
  • Commonly occurs following corneal scarring [or trauma].
  • Treatment of choice – Rigid contact lens to replace the anterior corneal surface.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spectacles - Glasses can correct regular astigmatism, but they are usually not effective for irregular astigmatism because they cannot compensate for the uneven curvature of the cornea.

 

Option C. INTACS - These are corneal implants designed to flatten the cornea and are sometimes used to treat irregular astigmatism, particularly in cases related to keratoconus, a condition that leads to a cone-shaped distortion of the cornea.

 

Option D. Phakic Intraocular lens - This is an artificial lens implanted inside the eye without removing the natural lens. It is generally used in patients with high degrees of myopia or hyperopia and is less commonly used for astigmatism, especially irregular astigmatism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for a patient presenting with irregular astigmatism is the use of rigid gas permeable contact lenses or scleral lenses, as they provide a uniform refractive surface that corrects the irregular curvature of the cornea.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 593

questions.text: An optician prescribes a power of -3.00DS / -0.50DC x 180°. The type of astigmatism noted is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Compound Myopic Astigmatism

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • Spectacles for astigmatism have 3 components:
    1. Spherical lens: Concave (-) or Convex (+) power expressed as Dioptre Sphere (DS).
    2. Cylindrical lens: Concave (-) or Convex (+) power expressed as Dioptre Cylinder (DC).
    3. Cylindrical axis.
       
  • In the given question, the prescription is -3.00DS / -0.50DC x 180°.
    1. Concave spherical lens of -3D power indicates the rays from this meridian focus in front of the retina.
    2. Cylindrical lens of -0.5D power indicates the rays from this meridian also focus in front of the retina.
    3. Axis of the cylinder is at 180°.
       
  • As mentioned in the table above, if rays from both the meridian focus in front of the retina, it is a case of Compound myopic astigmatism.

 

Option A. Simple myopic astigmatism - This occurs when one principal meridian is emmetropic (normal), and the other is myopic. Since there is a myopic correction in both meridians in this prescription, it is not simple myopic astigmatism.

 

Option C. Mixed astigmatism - This occurs when one principal meridian is myopic, and the other is hypermetropic (farsighted). The given prescription does not have a hypermetropic component, so it is not mixed astigmatism.

 

Option D. Compound hypermetropic astigmatism with presbyopia - This would involve hypermetropic corrections in both meridians, with different powers, and an additional correction for presbyopia, which is not indicated in this prescription.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prescription of -3.00DS / -0.50DC x 180° is indicative of compound myopic astigmatism, where both principal meridians are myopic with different dioptre strengths.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana 37

questions.text: This test is based on?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chromatic Aberration

 

  • The given test is Duo chrome test.
  • It is based on the principle of chromatic aberration.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Interference - This is a phenomenon where waves overlap, and the resulting wave amplitude is either increased (constructive interference) or decreased (destructive interference). Polarised glasses are used in tests evaluating stereopsis.

 

Option C. Prismatic effect - This occurs when light is bent as it passes through a prism. Prisms are used for evaluation and management of squint.

 

Option D. Diffraction - This involves the bending of light waves around obstacles and the spreading of light from a coherent source. Edges of IOLS are designed to reduce diffraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The duo chrome test is based on the principle of chromatic aberration, which is utilized to fine-tune the refractive power needed for vision correction by comparing the focus of red and green light on the retina.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 588

questions.text: A child was referred from school screening camp due to difficulty in seeing blackboard. The teacher mentioned that he was squinting (half-shutting) his eyes while seeing the blackboard. What do you think is the probable cause for this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Myopia

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of myopia include –

 

  • Defective distant vision hence it is also known as near-sightedness.
  • Asthenopia symptoms
  • Squinting (half-shutting) of eyes – this is done to achieve greater clarity of stenopaeic vision.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 33

questions.text: A 12-year-old female student complains of experiencing blurred vision and difficulty seeing objects in the distance. On examination, her eyes appeared normal with vision of 6/6 in both eyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudo Myopia

 

Option B: A school-going girl experiencing difficulty in seeing distant objects while having a visual acuity of 6/6 suggests a diagnosis of Pseudo myopia. It has been caused most probably due to increase in near-work like reading, writing, or using digital devices leading to overstimulation of ciliary muscle.

 

MYOPIA TYPES

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Index myopia refers to myopia caused by changes in the refractive index of the lens or other ocular media, often related to metabolic changes, and would not usually resolve to show a normal vision of 6/6 during an eye examination.

 

Option C. Simple myopia, or true myopia, is a permanent change in the eye where the eyeball is too long relative to the focusing power of the cornea and lens. This would usually result in a permanent decrease in distance vision, not intermittent symptoms.

 

Option D. Induced myopia can be caused by various factors, including medications, increased blood sugar levels, or exposure to various environmental factors. Like index myopia, it would not typically present with normal vision during an examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis for a patient experiencing blurred distance vision intermittently but showing normal vision on examination is pseudo myopia, which is often due to a transient spasm of the ciliary muscles after prolonged close work.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition Page 71

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of gradually worsening vision over the past year. The ophthalmologist plans to assess the patient's refractive state objectively to determine the appropriate course of action. Which test would he carry out for the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Skiascopy

 

Option B:

 

  • Skiascopy, also known as Retinoscopy or Shadow test is an objective method of finding out refractive error by the method of neutralization.
  • Other objective methods of refraction testing: Refractometry and Keratometry.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ophthalmoscopy: Clinical exam of Retina. It is of 3 types: Distant direct, Direct and Indirect.

 

Option C. Gonioscopy: Examination of angle of anterior chamber.

 

Option D. Campimetry: also known as Scotometry, is done to evaluate the central and paracentral area of visual field.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skiascopy (Retinoscopy) is the appropriate test to objectively assess a patient's refractive error to determine the necessary correction for conditions like myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 580

questions.text: During an eye examination, a 40-year-old patient presented with complaints of blurred vision and difficulty reading. While performing keratometry, it was observed that the horizontal meridian exhibited a higher degree of curvature compared to the vertical meridian. Based on these findings, the likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Against the Rule Astigmatism

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. With the rule astigmatism - With the rule astigmatism is characterized by a greater curvature of the cornea in the vertical meridian than in the horizontal meridian

 

Option C. Oblique astigmatism - In this type, the steepest curve lies in an oblique axis, neither horizontal nor vertical.

 

Option D. Bioblique astigmatism - This occurs when both principal meridians are oblique and at different angles that are neither vertical nor horizontal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Against the rule astigmatism is when the horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian. This type of astigmatism is commonly corrected with glasses or contact lenses that have the appropriate cylindrical correction.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 36

questions.text: A patient had a refractive error of -5D in the right eye and -7.5D in left eye. The difference in size of retinal image would be.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5%

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above condition is suggestive of ANISOMETROPIA – unequal refraction in both eyes.
  • 1D difference between two eyes produces 2% difference in retinal image.
  • Difference of more than 2.5D causes more than 5% difference in retinal images of the two eyes. Up to 5% can be tolerated.
  • Here, since difference is 2.5D, the retinal images will differ by 5%.

 

 

By taking into account the magnification factor for lenses, which for myopic correction is approximately given by the formula:

 

Magnification=11−(0.014×Lens Power in Diopters)

 

Magnification=1−(0.014×Lens Power in Diopters)1

 

For both eyes, we will calculate the magnification factor and then determine the percentage difference in image size based on these magnification factors. Let's perform this corrected calculation.

 

The corrected calculation shows that the difference in size of the retinal image between the two eyes is approximately 3.9%, which would be closest to option D, 5%.

 

Students do not need to learn this calculation. The approximations mentioned in the table are clinically relevant and need to be remembered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a refractive error of -5D in the right eye and -7.5D in the left eye, the approximate difference in retinal image size is 5%.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 38

questions.text: The site of placement of this segment is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intrastromal 

 

Option A:

 

  • The picture shows presence of Intracorneal ring segments.
  • It is implanted at the peripheral cornea at approximately 2/3rd stromal depth.
  • Vaulting effect causes flattening of central cornea. Hence, is used in treatment of Keratoconus.
  • Advantage – Reversible.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Descemet’s Membrane - This is a thin but strong film of tissue that serves as the protective barrier between the corneal stroma and the endothelial layer of the cornea. It is not suitable for the placement of INTACS as it is too deep and its integrity is crucial for the health of the endothelial cells that are responsible for keeping the cornea dehydrated and transparent.

 

Option C. Intraepithelial - This refers to within the epithelial layer, which is the outermost layer of the cornea. It provides a barrier to protect the cornea against foreign particles and absorbs oxygen and nutrients from tears. INTACS are not placed here because the epithelial layer is too thin and constantly regenerates, which would not provide a stable position for the rings.

 

Option D. Subepithelial - This refers to beneath the epithelial layer but above the stroma. This location is also not suitable for the placement of INTACS as it could interfere with the regenerative capability of the epithelium and is not deep enough to allow for the desired refractive changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

INTACS rings are placed intrastromally within the corneal stroma to utilize the thickness and structural integrity of the stroma for reshaping the cornea to correct refractive errors.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 48

questions.text: Most common form of Myopia is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Axial Myopia

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Index myopia - These results from changes in the refractive index of the eye's media, usually the lens, which can occur with conditions such as nuclear cataract or in cases of blood sugar fluctuations (as in diabetes).

 

Option B. Positional myopia - This is a less common term that might refer to myopia caused by the lens being positioned too close to the cornea, but it is not a widely recognized classification.

 

Option C. Curvatural myopia - This form of myopia occurs due to an increase in the curvature of the cornea or lens, which causes light rays to be over-converged and focus in front of the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Axial myopia is the most common form of myopia and is caused by the elongation of the axial length of the eye, leading to distant objects being focused in front of the retina and appearing blurred.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 33

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient who previously underwent cataract surgery resulting in aphakia is prescribed spectacles for visual correction. She has been using the spectacles regularly, and now complains of experiencing a specific type of visual impairment or blind spot. What type of scotoma do you think she may have developed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Roving Ring Scotoma

 

Option D:

 

Aphakia means absence of crystalline lens from the eye. It produces high degree of hypermetropia, which it has to be treated with Convex lenses.

 

  • The modalities of correction can be:
    1. Spectacles (like in this case)
    2. Contact lens
    3. Introcular lens
    4. Refractive corneal surgery

 

  • Disadvantages of such high-power spectacles include -
    • Image appears magnified (30%)
    • Spherical aberration
    • Chromatic aberration
    • Limited field of vision
    • Prismatic effect
    • Roving ring scotoma (JACK IN THE BOX PHENOMENON)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Siedel scotoma - This is associated with a glaucomatous defect near the blind spot and is not related to the correction of aphakia with spectacles.

 

Option B. Scintillating scotoma - This is a type of visual aura commonly associated with migraine, which appears as a flickering, jagged arc of light.

 

Option C. Bjerrum scotoma - This is a visual field defect associated with glaucoma, typically a wedge-shaped scotoma extending from the blind spot horizontally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In aphakic patients corrected with spectacles, a roving ring scotoma can develop due to peripheral visual field distortions caused by the prismatic effect of the strong plus lens required to correct the absence of the crystalline lens.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 32

choices.text: Single Layer of Epithelial Cells

questions.text: A 65-year-old man came to the ophthalmologist with a complaint of gradually increasing blurring of vision in both his eyes since 1 year. After examination, he was diagnosed with bilateral mature senile cataract and was explained how his lenses had lost their transparency leading to blurring of vision. Factors that play significant role in maintaining the outstanding clarity of normal lens are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vascularity

 

Option C: Causes of Lens Transparency:

 

  • Single layer of epithelial cells
  • Tightly packed lens proteins
  • Pump mechanism
  • Avascularity
  • Auto oxidation of glutathione

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The lens is covered by a single layer of epithelial cells on its anterior surface. These cells are essential for lens growth and transparency. They help regulate water and ion balance in the lens and produce lens fibers, which are crucial for maintaining lens clarity.

 

Option B. Lens has natural auto oxidation mechanism.

 

Option D. The lens contains ion channels and pumps that help maintain its dehydration and precise ion balance, which are essential for lens transparency. Disruption in this pump mechanism can lead to cataract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lens is an avascular structure, meaning it lacks blood vessels. This avascularity is crucial for its transparency. If the lens were vascularized, the blood vessels would interfere with light transmission and clarity.

 

Ref: 127/ Anatomy and Physiology of Eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd Edition

questions.text: The Percentage Distribution of Water & Proteins in Crystalline Lens respectively, is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 65%, 35%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Main constituents of the lens are Water (65%) & Proteins (35%).

 

Ref: Pg 118/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: In the lens, what is/are the pathway(s) involved in the metabolism of glucose?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D: Glucose Metabolism in the lens:

 

  1. Anaerobic Glycolysis
  2. Kerb’s Cycle
  3. HMP Pathway
  4. Sorbitol Pathway

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle) is a key metabolic pathway that generates energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. However, in the lens, the Krebs cycle plays a minimal role because the lens operates in a relatively hypoxic environment and relies more on anaerobic glycolysis for its energy requirements.

 

Option B. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP Pathway), also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is an important metabolic pathway in the lens. It provides the lens with NADPH, which is crucial for maintaining reduced glutathione levels. Reduced glutathione is vital for protecting the lens against oxidative stress, thus helping maintain its transparency and preventing cataract formation.

 

Option C. Sorbitol Pathway, also known as the polyol pathway, involves the conversion of glucose to sorbitol by the enzyme aldose reductase. In the lens, this pathway becomes particularly active in hyperglycemic conditions, such as in diabetes, and can lead to the accumulation of sorbitol. Excessive accumulation of sorbitol can cause osmotic stress, leading to lens swelling, opacification, and cataract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose metabolism in the lens is through Krebs cycle, HMP pathway and Sorbitol pathway.

 

Ref: Pg 123/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which enzyme is implicated in Classic Galactosaemic, an inborn error of Galactose Metabolism that leads to the development of Cataracts in Infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GALPUT (Galactose 1 Phosphate Uridyltransferase)

 

Option A:

 

  • In classic galactosemia, there is deficiency of GALPUT (Galactose 1 Phosphate Uridyltransferase).

 

 

  • Absence of GALPUT leads to accumulation of galactose and other toxic substances (such as galactitol) which leads to accumulation of water and leads to cataract (‘Oil-drop cataract’).
  • Cataract may be prevented if milk & milk products are eliminated from the diet.
  • Symptoms (Failure to Thrive, Jaundice, Hepatomegaly, Infantile Cataracts) develop when infant begins feeding (Lactose present in Breast Milk and formula feed).
  • Can predispose to E.coli sepsis in neonates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Galactokinase deficiency is another form of galactosemia, known as galactokinase deficiency galactosemia.

 

Option C. Aldose Reductase is involved in the polyol pathway, where it reduces glucose to sorbitol. While important in the context of diabetes-related cataract formation, it is not the enzyme implicated in classic galactosemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GALPUT (Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase) Deficiency leads to classic Galactosemia, which is associated with the development of cataracts in infants.

 

Ref: Pg 134/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Absence of which of the following enzymes in the sorbitol pathway leads to accumulation of excess sugar?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sorbitol Dehydrogenase 

 

 

 

Fig: Polyol (Sorbitol) pathway

 

  • Aldose Reductase is the sorbitol pathway enzyme which converts the excess sugar in the lens to the corresponding sugar alcohol. Thus, if it is deficient, there is an accumulation of sugar (glucose).
  • The deficiency of Sorbitol dehydrogenase causes intracellular accumulation of sorbitol leading to osmotic changes resulting in hydropic lens fibers that degenerate and form sugar cataracts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hexokinase catalyzes the first step in glycolysis, the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. While it's important in glucose metabolism, it is not directly involved in the sorbitol pathway. Hexokinase deficiency would affect glycolysis but not specifically lead to the accumulation of excess sugar in the sorbitol pathway.

 

Option C. Aldose Reductase catalyzes the reduction of glucose to sorbitol, the first step in the sorbitol pathway. However, a deficiency in aldose reductase would actually lead to less sorbitol being produced from glucose, not more.

 

Option D.Galactokinase is involved in galactose metabolism, not the sorbitol pathway. It catalyzes the phosphorylation of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate. Galactokinase deficiency leads to a different type of galactosemia but would not directly cause the accumulation of sorbitol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence or deficiency of Sorbitol Dehydrogenase in the sorbitol pathway leads to the accumulation of sorbitol, as it cannot be efficiently converted to fructose, leading to osmotic stress in cells and formation of cataract.

 

Ref:  Pg 135/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What can be prevented by inhibiting Aldol Reductase in Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic Cataract

 

Option A:

  • Aldose reductase is the sorbitol pathway enzyme which converts the excess sugar in the lens to the corresponding sugar alcohol.
  • The intracellular accumulation of sorbitol leads to osmotic changes resulting in hydropic lens fibres that degenerate and form sugar cataracts.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While diabetic nephropathy is a major complication of diabetes, the role of aldose reductase in its development is less direct compared to its role in cataracts.

 

Option C. Diabetic Neuropathy is also a complication where aldose reductase plays a role. Increased activity of the polyol pathway in nerve cells can lead to osmotic and oxidative stress, contributing to nerve damage. Inhibiting aldose reductase can therefore potentially help in preventing or slowing the progression of diabetic neuropathy.

 

Option D. Deafness: While diabetes can lead to a range of complications, there is no direct evidence linking aldose reductase activity to diabetes-related deafness. Deafness in diabetic patients is more commonly associated with other factors such as microvascular complications and neuropathies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most direct and well-established effect of inhibiting aldose reductase in the context of diabetes is the prevention of Diabetic Cataract

 

Ref:  Pg 135/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd Edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: 2-year-old child is diagnosed with a high refractive error of -9 D. Which of the following form of squint is likely to develop in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Esotropia

 

Option A:

 

  • The convergent (inward) misalignment of one eye is defined as esotropia.
  • It develops to preferentially see at its far point.
  • It is seen commonly in congenital myopes with high degrees of refractive error.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. A divergent (outward) misalignment: Exotropia.

 

Option C. An upward misalignment: Hypertropia.

 

Option D. A downward misalignment: Hypotropia.

 

Education Objective:

 

Refractive errors in children under the age of 5 years have a tendency to develop esotropia.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 33

questions.text: In LASEK, which of the following substance is used for rising flap of epithelium?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alcohol

 

Option C:

 

  • In order to minimize microkeratome related complications – there came use of alcohol to lift a thin flap of epithelium.
  • In LASEK, diluted alcohol (usually around 18-20%) is used to loosen and soften the epithelium, making it easier to create a flap. This is a key step in the LASEK procedure, distinguishing it from other refractive surgeries like LASIK.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Povidone-iodine: Antiseptic agent

 

Option B. Carboxymethyl cellulose: Artificial tears

 

Option D. Sodium chloride: Hypertonic solution which helps in reducing edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In LASEK, diluted alcohol is utilized to facilitate the gentle lifting of the epithelial flap, a critical step differentiating it from other refractive procedures.

 

Ref: Parson Diseases of eye 22nd edition page 83

questions.text: What is the total dioptric power in a Donders’ reduced eye model?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) + 60D

 

Option B: The concept of reduced eye: Instead of the eye being a combination of multiple refracting surfaces (cornea, aqueous humor, lens, vitreous humor), it is imagined as a single, ideal spherical refracting surface to understand the focusing mechanism of the eye as an optical device.

 

PARAMETERS IN DONDER’S REDUCED EYE MODEL

 

  • Principal Point – 1.5mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Nodal Point – 7.2mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Anterior Focal Point – 15.7mm in front of anterior surface of cornea
  • Posterior Focal Point – 24.23mm behind anterior surface of cornea
  • Total Dioptric Power +60D (+43D cornea and +17D lens)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. +58.64D: This value is close to the actual combined dioptric power of the human eye, but it's slightly less than the standard value used for the reduced eye model.

 

Option C. +43D: This value is the power of the cornea in the reduced eye model.

 

Option D. +53D: This is also lower than the typical total dioptric power of the human eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total dioptric power of the reduced eye, a simplified model of the human eye, is conventionally set at +60 diopters, encompassing the combined refractive powers of the cornea and the lens.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 26

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for squint. Which of the following angles can be measured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Kappa

 

Option D:

 

  • Kappa angle is between line of sight (pupillary line) and visual axis.
  • Only angle kappa can be measured.
  • A positive angle kappa result in pseudo-exotropia
  • A negative angle kappa result in pseudo-esotropia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alpha: The angle alpha is the angle between the optical axis and the visual axis of the eye. It's a conceptual angle more than a measurable one in clinical practice.

 

Option B. Beta: This angle is not commonly referenced in standard ophthalmological practice for measurement.

 

Option C. Gamma: Like beta, the gamma angle is also not a standard measurable angle in the context of clinical ophthalmology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ophthalmology, the angle Kappa, which is the angle between the visual axis and the pupillary axis, is a measurable parameter that holds clinical significance, especially in refractive surgery and binocular vision assessments.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 27

questions.text: Functional Hypermetropia occurs in which of the nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oculomotor nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • Functional hypermetropia is the difficulty in reading or seeing nearby objects due to paralysis of accommodation.
  • Accommodation has 3 components:
    1. Constriction of pupil: via Sphincter pupillae
    2. Convergence: via Medial Recti
    3. Curvature increases of lens: via Ciliary muscle contraction
       
  • These 3 things are mediated via Oculomotor nerve.
  • Thus, Functional hypermetropia is seen in patients with third nerve palsy and internal ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of sphincter and dilator pupillae).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): This nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, which primarily contributes to the rotation of the eye. Trochlear nerve palsy affects eye movement but does not directly impact accommodation or refractive status like hypermetropia.

 

Option C. Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): The abducens nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abduction. Palsy of this nerve leads to an inability to move the eye laterally, but it does not affect accommodation or cause hypermetropia.

 

Option D. Optic Nerve (Cranial Nerve II): The optic nerve transmits visual information from the retina to the brain. Palsy or damage to the optic nerve affects vision, but it does not cause hypermetropia as it is not involved in the accommodation process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional hypermetropia can occur as a result of oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III) palsy, which impairs the ciliary muscle's ability to accommodate, leading to difficulty focusing on near objects.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page 29

questions.text: A patient with high myopia asks for thinner glasses. What is the ideal refractive index of the glass material that can be used?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.67

 

Option B:

 

  • Patients with high refractive errors require very thick lenses of crown glass, providing poor peripheral vision and cosmesis.
  • High index lenses that are available in glass or plastic have a refractive index of 1.56–1.67, as compared to 1.52 for crown glass.
  • The lenses are therefore thinner, flatter and lighter.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1.52: This is a standard refractive index for regular plastic lenses. While they are lighter than glass, lenses made with this refractive index for high myopia would still be relatively thick.

 

Option C. 2.12: Materials with such high refractive indices are generally not used in standard eyewear due to cost, weight, and manufacturing challenges.

 

Option D. 2.57: Materials with such high indices are not common place in the optical industry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with high myopia seeking thinner glasses, lenses made of high-index materials, such as those with a refractive index of 1.67, are ideal. They offer a thinner and lighter solution compared to standard lens materials.

 

Ref: Parson Disease of eye 22nd edition Page 81
